natural problem: A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later?
natural solution: Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bacteria :: real
assumes h0 : "bacteria = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria * (2 powr (t / 4)) = bacteria * (2 powr (t / 4))"
shows  "bacteria * (2 powr (12 / 4)) = 4800"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes bacteria :: real
assumes h0 : "bacteria = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria * (2 powr (t / 4)) = bacteria * (2 powr (t / 4))"
shows  "bacteria * (2 powr (12 / 4)) = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A bacteria culture initially has 600 bacteria. The number of bacteria doubles every 4 hours. How many bacteria will there be after 12 hours? The final answer is 4800.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes t0 t1 pop0 pop1 :: real
assumes h0 : "t0 = 12"
and h1 : "t1 = 24"
and h2 : "pop0 = 600"
and h3 : "\<forall> t. t \<ge> t0 \<and> t < t1 \<longrightarrow> pop1 t = pop0 * 2 powr ((t - t0) / 4)"
shows  "pop1 t1 = 4800"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes t0 t1 pop0 pop1 :: real
assumes h0 : "t0 = 12"
and h1 : "t1 = 24"
and h2 : "pop0 = 600"
and h3 : "\<forall> t. t \<ge> t0 \<and> t < t1 \<longrightarrow> pop1 t = pop0 * 2 powr ((t - t0) / 4)"
shows  "pop1 t1 = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A population starts with 600 individuals at time $t_0 = 12$. The population doubles every 4 hours from $t_0$ to $t_1 = 24$. What is the population at time $t_1$? The final answer is 4800.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes population :: real
and initial_population :: real
and doubling_time :: real
and time_elapsed :: real
assumes h0 : "initial_population = 600"
and h1 : "doubling_time = 4"
and h2 : "time_elapsed = 12"
and h3 : "population = initial_population * 2 powr (time_elapsed / doubling_time)"
shows  "population = 4800"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes population :: real
and initial_population :: real
and doubling_time :: real
and time_elapsed :: real
assumes h0 : "initial_population = 600"
and h1 : "doubling_time = 4"
and h2 : "time_elapsed = 12"
and h3 : "population = initial_population * 2 powr (time_elapsed / doubling_time)"
shows  "population = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A population of 600 organisms doubles every 4 hours. How many organisms will there be after 12 hours? The final answer is 4800.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bacteria :: real and t :: nat
assumes h0 : "bacteria = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria * (2 powr (t div 4)) = bacteria * (2 powr (t div 4))"
and h2 : "t = 12"
shows  "bacteria * (2 powr (t div 4)) = 4800"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes bacteria :: real and t :: nat
assumes h0 : "bacteria = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria * (2 powr (t div 4)) = bacteria * (2 powr (t div 4))"
and h2 : "t = 12"
shows  "bacteria * (2 powr (t div 4)) = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A colony of bacteria starts with 600 individuals. The population of the colony doubles every 4 hours. After 12 hours, find the total number of bacteria in the colony. The final answer is 4800.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bacteria :: real
assumes h0 : "bacteria = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria * (2 powr (t / 4)) = bacteria * (2 powr (3 * t))"
and h2 : "t = 12"
shows  "bacteria * (2 powr (3 * t)) = 4800"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes bacteria :: real
assumes h0 : "bacteria = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria * (2 powr (t / 4)) = bacteria * (2 powr (3 * t))"
and h2 : "t = 12"
shows  "bacteria * (2 powr (3 * t)) = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A bacteria culture initially has 600 bacteria, and the number of bacteria doubles every 4 hours. Find the number of bacteria in the culture after 12 hours. The final answer is 4800.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes population :: real
assumes h0 : "population = 600"
and h1 : "population * 2 powr (x / 4) = midnight_population"
and h2 : "x = 12"
shows  "midnight_population = 4800"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes population :: real
assumes h0 : "population = 600"
and h1 : "population * 2 powr (x / 4) = midnight_population"
and h2 : "x = 12"
shows  "midnight_population = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If the population of a town is 600 at a certain time, and it doubles every 4 hours, what will be the population at midnight if 12 hours have passed since the initial population count? The final answer is 4800.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes population :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "population 0 = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. population (t + 1) = 2 * population t"
shows  "population 3 = 4800"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes population :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "population 0 = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall> t. population (t + 1) = 2 * population t"
shows  "population 3 = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A population starts with 600 individuals. At each time step, the population doubles. What is the population after 3 time steps? The final answer is 4800.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes population :: real
assumes h0 : "population = 600"
and h1 : "population * (2^(12/4)) = 4800"
shows  "4800 = population * (2^(12/4))"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes population :: real
assumes h0 : "population = 600"
and h1 : "population * (2^(12/4)) = 4800"
shows  "4800 = population * (2^(12/4))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If the initial population is 600, find the population after 12 quarters with a growth rate that doubles every 4 quarters. The final population is 4800.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bacteria :: real and hours :: nat
assumes h0 : "bacteria 0 = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. bacteria (n + 1) = 2 * bacteria n"
and h2 : "hours = 12"
and h3 : "hours = 4 * n"
shows  "bacteria n = 4800"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof
 Twelve hours later is three four-hour intervals later, so the population will double three times. The population size will be $600\times2\times2\times2=600\times2^3=\boxed{4800}$ bacteria.
 *)

theorem
fixes bacteria :: real and hours :: nat
assumes h0 : "bacteria 0 = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. bacteria (n + 1) = 2 * bacteria n"
and h2 : "hours = 12"
and h3 : "hours = 4 * n"
shows  "bacteria n = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A colony of bacteria starts with 600 bacteria and doubles every hour. How many bacteria will there be after 12 hours? The final answer is 4800.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bacteria_population :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bacteria_population 0 = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria_population t = bacteria_population 0 * 2 powr (t / 4)"
shows  "bacteria_population 12 = 4800"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A population of bacteria is doubling every four hours. At noon there are $600$ bacteria. If this rate continues, how many bacteria will be present at midnight, twelve hours later? The final Answer is 4800
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes bacteria_population :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bacteria_population 0 = 600"
and h1 : "\<forall>t. bacteria_population t = bacteria_population 0 * 2 powr (t / 4)"
shows  "bacteria_population 12 = 4800"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A bacteria population starts with 600 bacteria and doubles every 4 hours. How many bacteria are there after 12 hours? The final answer is 4800.
